docs.lead_paragraph: The excitement over Mike Huckabee's rise in the polls reminded me of a column Nick wrote almost two years ago about the former Arkansas governor. The column had nothing to do with winning the presidency; it was about losing weight. After being told that he had obesity-related diabetes in 2003, the governor changed his diet, began running and lost 110 pounds. Here's what Nick wrote:

docs.abstract: Letters comment on Times Magazine articles; Philip G Cerny comments on Nov 25 article about boys from Moroccan village who grew up to be jihadist; Warren D Allmon, James S Mellett and Peter Hiller comment on Nov 25 article on 'young earth' creationists; Monica Ball and Marion Gropen comment on Nov 25 article on bear intrusions in Whistler, British Columbia; Mark E Horowitz, Francis W Rodgers, Amy N Ship, Olivia Koppell and Michael Banov comment on Dr Daniel Carlat's article on promoting a Wyeth drug to other psychiatrists; Joan Gillman Smith comments on Billy Collins's Nov 25 poem; Michael Brun comments on Nov 4 article on Venezuelan oil industry; Christopher Pelham comments on Nov 18 interview with Michael Eisner; Carolyn Parkinson comments on Virginia Heffernan's Nov 18 column on Sesame Street; Beth Marchant comments on Nov 11 article on John Ford's The Searchers; Arthur Z Moss comments on Nov 18 article on Pansychism; photos
docs.lead_paragraph: Where Boys Grow Up to Be Jihadis Andrea Elliott's article (Nov. 25) on why (and where) boys become jihadis provides an excellent, nuanced account of the conditions they grow up in. Nevertheless, the basic cause is still obscure. Her analysis reminds me of a phrase: ''the revolution of rising expectations.''
